> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [d3abe2c...09f44bc](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/d3abe2c3c2dd2ef53b00282de9f9e3a4512ab068...09f44bce5bb8ca4fbf1afd365084631022a23262?src=pr)
@bolkedebruin - Understood. How is this handled in datastores that do not support fractional seconds? Isn't this the main cause of the issue - datastores not supporting the accepted granularity?

We don't support those datastores as a backend for Airflow. 

MySQL 5.6.4+ changed its behavior towards fractional seconds. This means that if you do a comparison with a fractional part, ie. datetime.now(), it wont match against what is stored as MySQL's default is not to store fractional seconds. This has been fixed in master.

Officially we support MySQL and Postgres as a backend. Thus use Postgres or MySQL < 5.6.4 with Airflow 1.7.1.3 or use master with either Postgres and MySQL 5.6.4+.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [d3abe2c...9ff2cd2](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/d3abe2c3c2dd2ef53b00282de9f9e3a4512ab068...9ff2cd252feeae50bdf4e1ca2c8184bb12ebe7a9?src=pr)

My experience with Airflow 1.7.1.3 / Postgres 9.3.13 or 9.5.4 / SQLAlchemy 1.1.4 and fractional seconds was unstable behavior due to mismatch in the timestamp. I did not experience this with SQLite (default) which doesn't support fractional second granularity. Removing the fractional second granularity from the table definitions resolved this. I recall looking at the SQLAlchemy code but can't find the code section at the moment. It automatically adjusts for DB type precision during comparisons which corrects for comparisons to datetime.now() with higher precision.

Rebased and running tests on a side branch on my fork now. When they pass,
I'll push to the tracked branch.

Thanks,
Ben

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [410736d...798093c](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/410736dbc440d643fb3ea5f2094b64b8d4e3ba3b...798093c285b217ecb36d8c606553206303b8b6ef?src=pr)

I disagree with that approach for a few reasons. 

Firstly, I'd prefer fewer (ideally a single) means to achieve a goal in Airflow, rather than multiple half-measures. If a user wants to pause a DAG, he/she should be provide a single, conspicuous, intuitive means to pause the DAG. The current solution for that is the "Pause DAG" UI control, now found on every DAG-centric UI Page. Setting the slot size to 0 is a hack. Also, it interferes with a lot of best practices around configuration management. Connections, Pools, & Variables are all part of configuration and should ideally be controlled by configuration management tooling (e.g. Ansible, Chef, Puppet, etc...). Manually altering these is hacky. Worse yet, altering them opens the door to forgetting about it and then having to track down why a DAG is not running. 

This happened to us in production. It was not at all obvious why a DAG stopped running and we needed to follow a process of elimination to figure it out.

Secondly, what do you expect to happen when the pool size is set to 0? I'd expect to see queued tasks. In 1.7.1.3, which is what we run in production, this does not happen. Instead, there are no state indicators on the DAG or Tree views. This situation falls in the "why is the DAG not being scheduled" category, which I hope you agree should be minimized. 

I'd rather have an exception surface when a pool does not exist or to see queued tasks, both of which make it easy to diagnose and resolve an issue. A 0-slot pool is currently a silent error. We could submit a fix in the scheduler for this as well, though when I consider my first point, I'd prefer to disallow silly things like an empty resource pool. 

The pain of a 0-slot pool outweighs its value IMO.
should this go under airflow/contrib/sensors ?

I understand your points however I think the behaviour changed in master and some people might actually use it. So maybe it is an idea to discuss this on the mailinglist first. Maybe a warning is better?
Yes, I believe you are correct. I have moved the sensor to contrib.
This makes total sense. I like that the project is moving towards a path where state is more easily determined. I'd like to see some sort of unit test (even basic) to be apart of the PR also.

@bolkedebruin I've tested the existing behavior on latest master (without my fix). 

Including other maintainers : @jlowin @criccomini 

Master has a new state `scheduled`, not present in 1.7.1.3. Currently, if the pool size is set to 0, the state indicator on the tree view is a black square for `scheduled` -- `note : the graph view doesn't show any state indicator and tree view is actually missing a legend entry for this new scheduled state.`, so these should have been part of the original PR that added the `scheduled` state.

Having the new `scheduled` state is helpful, but I'd prefer to see tasks `queued` not `scheduled` in this case. There may be other reasons a task is stuck in the `scheduled` state but a `queued` entry is more directly attributable to a pool oversubscription issue. 

Additionally, this does not address my first point : using the Pause DAG controls now  available in the UI, CLI, and possibly API.
Here are some screen shots from master.

**Pool Entry - Slots set to 0**
https://www.dropbox.com/s/8f1j36uoit4m90y/Screenshot%202016-12-31%2009.57.40.png?dl=0

**Tree View - Take Note of Scheduled State for First Task Depending on Pool**
https://www.dropbox.com/s/h06o69ozyf8eojt/Screenshot%202016-12-31%2009.57.07.png?dl=0

**Graph View - Take Note There is no Task State Indicator for this Case**
https://www.dropbox.com/s/diw8dne28oohf1r/Screenshot%202016-12-31%2009.56.54.png?dl=0

**Code View - Notice Task that uses the Pool**
https://www.dropbox.com/s/k0ly4bc1ov6qjf8/Screenshot%202016-12-31%2009.55.46.png?dl=0

I think it's a good thing to be able to disable a pool [temporarily], and setting it to 0 is probably the only way to do that currently. Say if you'd have a Redshift pool use across many DAGs, and would like to temporarily disable Redshift (say for some maintenance task), setting that pool to 0 would be easy and more targeted than pausing all the DAGs, which would also stop progress on other tasks which in theory can run.

I agree that we should formalize the `scheduled` state, with a specific, coherent color and representation throughout the UI

So to clarify what I'm seeing: 
- Sensor starts at 0:00 UTC
- Exactly one hour later it get's killed by the new duplicate process detection
- I saw a refresh of the DAG's before the kill (so I'm think it restarts a task).
So I'm not sure it's related (still need more digging around)
Oh, and it happens with Celary, not Local

@bolkedebruin I believe I've added wired it up in cli.py now. I was having a look at the tests for that to see if I could expand it. I think the only test is at line 1246 in tests/core.py and I don't think I fully understand what it's doing. Is it worth trying to improve it at this time?

I thought the desired behavior was to propagate the skipping so that the DAG run would end and allow the scheduler to move on. Ultimately your DAG will stop when concurrent number of DAG runs is reached. Whether the skipping state propagates or not, user action need to be taken for things to move forward.

I think it's fair to think that people may expect either behavior. People may have designed existing DAGs based on how this feature behaves. I think the main reason I'd prefer the current behavior is that is allows the scheduler to move forward.

In either case the branching section in the concepts part of the docs should be more clear about using the trigger rule one_success in the joining task. It should also be clear about how user should expect the `skipped` state to propagate. Thinking about it, the trigger rule `all_success` in a joining task is not logical. We could almost raise when/if detecting it.

@bolkedebruin I thought I'd found what I'd missed on this, but the unit-test is still failing, now with the exceptionally unhelpful error message "SystemExit: 2". I'll get back on this on Monday morning, but would very much appreciate any thoughts you have on what I've broken.
